homes_hear_details: Mississippi's HOMES and HEAR programs are pending launch. The Mississippi Development Authority - Energy Division is working on program design and implementation using approximately $50 million in IRA funding allocated to the state.

income_thresholds.low_income_80_ami: For a family of four in Jackson, 80% AMI is approximately $49,900. Low-income households will qualify for the highest rebate levels under HOMES when the program launches.
income_thresholds.moderate_income_150_ami: For a family of four in Jackson, 150% AMI is approximately $93,600. Moderate-income households will qualify for partial rebates under HOMES when the program launches.

net_metering: Mississippi established net metering rules in 2015 through the Mississippi Public Service Commission. Systems up to 2 MW qualify for net metering with investor-owned utilities. Excess generation is credited at the avoided cost rate. The rules apply to Entergy Mississippi and Mississippi Power. Rural electric cooperatives and municipal utilities may have separate policies.

state_tax_credits.name: Mississippi does not currently offer state tax credits for residential renewable energy or energy efficiency
state_tax_credits.details: Mississippi does not have state-level solar tax credits, energy efficiency tax credits, or renewable energy incentives for residential customers. Residents can still claim the federal 30% Investment Tax Credit for solar PV and battery storage.

state_rebate_programs.administrator: Mississippi Department of Human Services / Community Action Agencies
state_rebate_programs.eligible_items: Insulation, air sealing, HVAC repair and replacement, duct sealing, window and door repairs
state_rebate_programs.details: Available to households at or below 200% of the federal poverty level. Administered by local community action agencies throughout Mississippi.
